skill.name: diagnostic-action
skill.description: Use when the user asks why something happened, what is wrong, root cause analysis, debugging, or incident explanation.
skill.summary: Guides AI to identify and explain causes of problems through systematic diagnostic reasoning.
skill.author: BellaBe

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. This skill is a documentation-only guidance file for diagnostic reasoning. No executable code, network calls, file operations, or cryptographic functions exist. The static scanner misidentified metadata fields and plain text descriptions as security patterns.

content.value_statement: Users often struggle to identify why failures or errors occurred. This skill provides a structured framework for generating hypotheses, explaining mechanisms, and ranking causes by likelihood to guide effective debugging.
actual_capabilities: Restates symptoms and scope of the problem clearly
Generates multiple plausible hypotheses for the observed issue
Explains the mechanism behind each hypothesis
Ranks hypotheses by likelihood and potential impact
Identifies missing data that would help disambiguate causes
Provides structured diagnostic output without prescribing fixes
limitations: Does not provide recommendations or fixes for identified problems
Does not create plans or procedures for remediation
Cannot execute code or run tests to verify hypotheses
Relies on user-provided information about symptoms and context

use_cases.title: Software Debugging
use_cases.description: A developer encounters a cryptic error message or unexpected behavior in their application. The skill helps systematically explore potential causes such as race conditions, null pointer exceptions, configuration issues, or dependency conflicts.
use_cases.target_user: Software developers and engineers troubleshooting code issues

use_cases.title: Incident Post-Mortem Analysis
use_cases.description: An operations team experiences a system outage or service degradation. The skill guides the investigation through contributing factors, failure cascades, and root causes while distinguishing from proximate triggers.
use_cases.target_user: DevOps engineers, SREs, and incident responders

use_cases.title: Business Problem Investigation
use_cases.description: A product manager notices a drop in user engagement metrics. The skill helps brainstorm hypotheses about user behavior changes, technical issues, or external factors that could explain the observed symptom.
use_cases.target_user: Product managers, business analysts, and data scientists

prompt_templates.title: Basic Problem Description
prompt_templates.prompt: My application is not working as expected. Help me understand what might be causing this issue.
prompt_templates.scenario: User provides minimal information about a problem

prompt_templates.title: Error Message Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: I received this error message: [paste error]. What are the most likely causes of this error and how do they work?
prompt_templates.scenario: User has a specific error message to analyze

prompt_templates.title: System Behavior Investigation
prompt_templates.prompt: My system is exhibiting these symptoms: [describe symptoms]. I need to understand what could be happening under the hood.

prompt_templates.title: Complex Incident Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: We experienced an incident with these characteristics: [describe timeline, scope, and observations]. Help me run a diagnostic analysis to identify the most likely root causes.

output_examples.input: My database queries are running very slow today.
output: Symptoms & Scope: Database query performance degraded. All queries affected or specific ones? Timeframe: today. Impact: user-facing latency.
1. Lock contention (High confidence) - Concurrent writes blocking reads. Mechanism: Long-running transactions holding locks. Evidence: Check for recent schema changes or batch jobs.
2. Index fragmentation (Medium confidence) - Fragmented indexes causing full scans. Mechanism: Inserts/deletes without maintenance. Evidence: Run index statistics query.
3. Resource starvation (Medium confidence) - Competing workloads consuming CPU/memory. Mechanism: Other processes consuming resources. Evidence: Check system metrics.
Most Likely Causes: Lock contention from concurrent writes is most probable given sudden onset.
Data Needed: Active transactions, lock wait times, recent schema changes, resource utilization metrics.

output_examples.input: The API started returning 500 errors after we deployed a new release.
output: Symptoms & Scope: API returns HTTP 500 errors. All endpoints or specific ones? All users affected or subset?
1. Uncaught exception in new code (High confidence) - Code path not handling edge case. Mechanism: Runtime exception propagates to uncaught handler. Evidence: Check application logs for stack traces.
2. Database schema mismatch (Medium confidence) - Code expects column/table that does not exist. Mechanism: Migration not applied or incorrect order. Evidence: Compare schema versions.

3. Missing environment variable (Medium confidence) - New feature requires config that is not set. Mechanism: Startup failure or default fallback causing errors. Evidence: Check deployment configuration.
Most Likely Causes: Uncaught exception in new code is most probable.
Data Needed: Application logs from error occurrences, deployment manifests, environment configuration, database schema status.

best_practices: Always restate the problem in your own words to confirm understanding before generating hypotheses.
Generate at least three hypotheses with different root causes to avoid tunnel vision.
Identify what additional data or tests would help confirm or eliminate each hypothesis.
Avoid jumping to conclusions - rank hypotheses by evidence strength and impact.
anti_patterns: Prescribing solutions without first confirming the root cause through systematic analysis.
Focusing on only one hypothesis without exploring alternative explanations.
Confusing correlation with causation - just because two events occurred together does not mean one caused the other.
Skipping the step of identifying missing data that could disambiguate competing hypotheses.

faq.question: When should I use the diagnostic-action skill?
faq.answer: Use this skill when users ask questions like why something happened, what is wrong with their system, or request root cause analysis. It is appropriate for debugging scenarios, incident investigation, and failure analysis.

faq.question: What is the difference between diagnostic-action and prescriptive-action?
faq.answer: Diagnostic-action focuses on identifying and explaining causes of problems. Prescriptive-action provides recommendations and fixes. Use diagnostic first to understand the problem, then prescriptive if the user wants solutions.

faq.question: Can this skill fix the problems it diagnoses?
faq.answer: No. This skill focuses exclusively on identifying and explaining likely causes. It does not prescribe fixes or create remediation plans. Use planning-action or procedural-action for those tasks.

faq.question: Does this skill require access to my code or system?
faq.answer: No. This is a guidance skill that helps structure diagnostic reasoning. It works with information you provide about symptoms and context. It does not execute code or access files directly.

faq.question: How many hypotheses should I generate?
faq.answer: Generate at least three plausible hypotheses with different root causes. This prevents tunnel vision and helps ensure the actual cause is not missed. Rank them by likelihood and impact.

faq.question: What should I do with the output from this skill?
faq.answer: Use the structured output to guide further investigation. The hypotheses provide testable explanations. The identified missing data helps prioritize what information to gather next. Use this to reach a confident diagnosis before attempting fixes.
